lines.text:
[storms into the room and slaps the first man she sees]
Are you Peter Ames?
No...
But I am...
[Slaps Peter]

[Slaps Melsa]
To complete the circle.

[has just discovered Fonda is faking being near death, to pump her for information]
Are you still in pain, sweet?

[from hospital bed, faintly]
Oh its nothing, nothing... only when I move... but its nothing...

[hovering over hospital bed]
Peter, perhaps I did wrong in not telling Inspector Brent everything.
You mean you held something back?
Yes Peter.

[this is what he's hoping to hear]
Oh sweet, you're so clever.
Remember when I went into Ronnie Beldon's apartment?
Yes dear.
When I went into the bathroom, I found something.
In the bathroom?
Yes, floating around in a foot of water in the bathtub.
Louder, dear, I can hardly hear you.

[ominously]
I'll come closer.
Tell me dear, what was it?

[yelling]
The Normandie, you black-hearted faker, in full sail!
[stabs him in the leg with a fork]

Listen, before I knew you, I disliked you intensly. When I met you, I disliked you intensly. Even now, I dislike you intensly... that is, the sensible sane portion of me... but there;s an insane side of me that gets a little violent every time I think of you.
Getting out of a million dollar lawsuit wouldn't have anything to do with your change in affection, would it?
You're a nasty creature, aren't you, but in time I'll beat it out of you.
Look, lady, it's been ten minutes since you called us. The murderer, that is if there is a murderer, could be in Brooklyn by now - that is, if anybody *wants* to be in in Brooklyn.
Helen, you search the upstairs.
Oh, no! I was never much of an individualist. If the upstairs has to be searched, we'll search it together.
Why, that's communism!
You know, psychiatrists say hate's just a step away from love.
Yeah, but it's the lull in between that drives you crazy.

[to Melsa]
You're up to your beautiful hips in murder!
Miss Manton, I don't know what your game is but I know this - either your education or your spankin's been neglected. Now I can't do anything about spankin' ya, or can I?
Hilda, the door!

[already on her way to answer it]
I heard it. I ain't deaf. Sometimes I wished I was.

[tagging along after Hilda, talking with her mouth full]
Have you another piece of cake, Hilda?
Yes, I have, but the kitchen's closed for the night.
Hilda! Miss Beverly is our guest!
*I* didn't ask 'er up!
Comes the revolution and we'll stop being exploited by our help.
In my house the revolution is here.
Everybody suspects you of holding out, even I do.
Oh, I bet you say that to all the girls.
Don't speak to anyone. I don't want to kill an innocent bystander.
Ya know that's what I like about crazy men; that fine sense of distinction.
You think I'm insane?

[Stands in front of Peter, as to protect him]
Oh, he's says that to everybody.
We'll go to South America, for six months - maybe we'll never come back!
Can you afford it?
No, but you can.
Isn't there a drop of red blood in your veins? I want to live on your income!
That's foolish, who's going to live on yours?

[Referring to Melsa]
Isn't she wonderful? That's the girl I'm going to marry.
I'll take Snow White!

[to the telephoe operator]
Give me the Morrnin' Clarion. I don't know the numba'! The only numbers I knowse are policy numbers.

[to her friends]
Get him, girls!

[Nervously, then desparately as the girls engulf and subdue him]
Hey, wait a minute, girls...
[clicks the phone]
Tahe it easy, girls... look... Hello... Help, I tho... wha... ahh!...

[Talking about Melsa]
She's probably the kind of dame who would come back to haunt me. Otherwise, I'd shoot to kill.
Police! All they know is to blow a whistle and hold up traffic!
Round up that bag of dames that run around with Manton and bring them down to headquarters. Dreag 'em out of bed if you have to!
Are you kidding? I hope I have to!
Well, if I want to marry a fortune hunter, I can go to Europe and marry a professional one.
All right, Hilda, can you carry a gun?
No, suh! I'se a pacifist.
May I have a cigarette?
[He places one in her mouth, lights it]
I've had dozens of cigarette lighters but they never worked.
This just one just takes cheap gasoline.
Maybe that's why.

[throwing an entire pitcher of water in Peter's face]
sorry Mr. Ames, it was orders! but, I used distilled water.
Look! I found a bloodstain!
How can that be blood, it's blue!
Maybe he shot Mrs. Astor.
Thank you, Helen. You're sweet and very helpful.
